detail: There are about 100 or so loud vehicles (cars, vans, and motorcycles) that seem to gather somewhere down the street on a Sunday night. They then cause a commotion by driving loudly and quickly back up Kangley Bridge Road toward Stanton Way. Every Sunday, usually around 11pm. Our guess would be that they gather in commercial buildings / parking lots that aren't guarded on a weekend. This is a fairly busy road, but the traffic is largely unnoticeable generally speaking. These vehicles however cause a massive disruption -- partly b/c of number and speed, partly because at least half of them seem to be fitted with loud engines. Very disruptive activity and seems to be regular. Has been going on for at least a few weeks now.

title: Heavy electric buses are making our houses shake
description: Heavy electric buses are making our houses shake: Neighbours up and down the whole length of Sprules Road, ourselves included (at number 3), are complaining about our houses jolting and shaking violently whenever the new exceedingly heavy electric buses hit the speed bumps. Some of the driver go a little slower and the jolt is less noticeable but many hit the bumps without slowing and our houses jump as they do. Many neighbours have noticed new cracks and damage since the electric buses arrived in March 2021. We are all worrying about damage to the fascias, walls, and possibly even subsidence if the problem isn’t solved. The council is passing the buck to TfL. TfL apparently don’t accept that buses can damage houses 🙄 The bus company have apparently however asked drivers to drive slower, but as stated many of them hit the bumps at speed. A solution might be to cut grooves in the speed bumps to accommodate the buses’ wheels, or to re-route the bus route (though that could inconvenience the school), but something more than driver education needs to be done.

description: Very overgrown grass and plants adjacent to dwelling: The area of public grass and bushes adjacent to my house has been left neglected for ages. The foliage etc needs to be chopped back. When Glendale or whatever company is contacted now, come to do the mowing and gardening in Pagoda Gardens Estate they forget or fail to do any maintenance in this area. Why? It is an area of council land and should be kept tidy. Aren’t I paying my council tax for this? Please can this area be tidied up as it’s making this road (in a conservation area look shabby).

title: Missed recycling collection
description:
Missed recycling collection: Our main recycling bin has been full for over 10 days now. It was full before it was marked as contaminated over a week ago. Pinnacle have confirmed that they do not deal with these issues and they should be reported to Lewisham Council. Lewisham Council has said the opposite. For 15 months our block has lacked recycling capacity so we continue to dispose of recyclables in the normal waste bins. Neither Lewisham Council or Pinnacle seem to be accountable. A failed reporting and complaints system.

I have noticed that there is an option to select Lewisham Homes on my fix my street but not Regenter or Pinnacle so I guess Pinnacle is right and Lewisham Council is wrong. My service charge does not include bins but my Council Tax does so Lewisham Council is responsible but continues to do anything about it.
detail:
Our main recycling bin has been full for over 10 days now. It was full before it was marked as contaminated over a week ago. Pinnacle have confirmed that they do not deal with these issues and they should be reported to Lewisham Council. Lewisham Council has said the opposite. For 15 months our block has lacked recycling capacity so we continue to dispose of recyclables in the normal waste bins. Neither Lewisham Council or Pinnacle seem to be accountable. A failed reporting and complaints system.

I have noticed that there is an option to select Lewisham Homes on my fix my street but not Regenter or Pinnacle so I guess Pinnacle is right and Lewisham Council is wrong. My service charge does not include bins but my Council Tax does so Lewisham Council is responsible but continues to do anything about it.

title: Overflowing recycle bins again
detail:
For over one year residents have documented and reported a lack of recycling bin capacity for the block which is due to inappropriate bin lid types which means only one bin may be used. For over one year Pinnacle ignored these requests and Lewisham Council stated there was adequate bin capacity regardless of the photos. The Council then said the issue was due to contamination even though no red tags had been placed on the bins for a year. In the last month red contamination tags have been placed on the bins, after the bins were already full, and these tags have remained full for days after, so like the previous 15 months residents have been forced to place recyclables in the normal waste bins because of a lack of recycling bin capacity. Pinnacle (Regenter) have said that Lewisham Council is responsible for bin capacity and Lewisham Council has stated that Pinnacle (Regenter) is responsible so for over a year 1/4-1/3 of our recyclables have gone into normal waste bins and no-one is accountable for this.

Lewisham Council's default for these issues is to blame residents and state contamination. This is misleading and does not solve problems. Recycling bins are full long before collection dates, and even if there is contamination (which was not the case for over a year because no red tags) the contamination is limited and does not explain why the bins are full.

Overflowing recycling bins are then left for days, sometimes a week so residents have no choice but to throw away recyclables in normal waste bins.

Lewisham Council and Pinnacle's complaints system is based on apathy and grinding residents down so that their expectations are low enough to meet the Council's dismal and misleading standards.

detail:
The bridge over the River Quaggy is on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich with Bromley being the highway authority for the bridge and to the east of the bridge. West of the bridge Lewisham is the highway authority, and north of the bridge Greenwich is the highway authority.

Shown in the picture is the shiny new 10T weight restriction sign installed at Bromley taxpayers' expense to the east of the bridge. There are no weight restriction signs to the north of the bridge (Greenwich) or to the west of the bridge (Lewisham).

Lewisham assert that the bridge now has a 40T weight limit (presumably believing it has been strengthened) and they gleaned this information from Bromley.

Either Bromley has squandered taxpayers' money on the new sign or Lewisham has made a mistake in removing the 10T limit signs.

To further confuse matters, there is a second bridge over the River Quaggy this time on Mottingham Lane, again on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich, but with Greenwich the highway authority. Could it be that this bridge has the 10T limit.

Whatever the answer, this matter needs investigating as a matter of urgency, and the investigation should include liaising with Lewisham and Greenwich highway authorities to get to the bottom of this matter and ensuring that all three highway authorities display the correct signage for the bridge.

Bins full again - lack capacity because Lewisham Council inaction
description:
Bins full again - lack capacity because Lewisham Council inaction: For over a year I have documented and reported that our block lacked recycling bin capacity. I have reported this to Pinnacle, Regenter and Lewisham Council and none have taken any action to resolve this, they just put the finger at the other.

Two of our recycling bins are full again. One (the cardboard bin) has been full for a week, the other (bottle) for a few days. The third bin with bottle slots may only be partially used so residents have no choice but to put cardboard and other items in the normal waste bins.

Because of Lewisham Council and Pinnacle's ongoing neglect approx 25-30% of our recyclables have been placed in the wrong bins for over a year. Neither care about this and apparently no-one is accountable.

It is beyond incompetence and just a waste of tax payers money - Lewisham Council;

title: Large orange gas bottle fly tipped onto pavement by resident of either 38 or 38a holdenby road
detail:
A Large orange Gas Bottle has been put out onto pavement by residents of either number 38 or 38A Holdenby Road:

I reported the situation of residents at 38 and 38A leaving their Bins outside their properties obstructing the pavement for many days at a time and Fly tipping unwanted household items on the pavement outside their homes on the 3rd of May but evidently Lewisham Council have still not contacted them to instruct them to stop doing that as it is still happening:

Today - Monday 17th May some of the Bins have been left out [again] on the pavement since last Wednesday`s Bin emptying day.

They regularly leave either all 4 Bins or 2 of them out obstructing the pavement for many days - often more than a week.

I originally posted a report about that because it was obstructing the pavement when I was going past with my child`s buggy especially when other people were trying to walk past the bins - I sometimes have had to go out into the road to wait for people to pass the bins before proceeding - not desirable with a child in a buggy.

At no point since I reported this problem 12 days ago have all of the bins been put back onto the residents property / removed from the pavement.

Now one of the residents has put a large orange coloured Gas bottle outside on the pavement.

I wonder if there is still Gas in the bottle ?

I feel that this could be very dangerous if for example an inquisitive child tried to turn it on not realising that they should not touch it.

It is NOT good enough for the Council to just categorise this report / complaint as something like: `Passed to the Highways Department` - I cannot remember the exact term used for my previous report.

description: Recycling bins not collected again: For over a year Lewisham Council has failed to consistently collect the recycling bins for this Regenter (Pinnacle) managed block. Documented complaints have been made to both but still no action has been taken. Our bins were full before Easter and were not emptied this week so again residents have to use the normal waste bins to dispose of recyclables. Lewisham Council's contractors do not have the capacity to manage and deliver this contract to the required collection frequency and the estate does not have enough bins to cope with increased bin pressures due to COVID behavioural changes. The bins have not been contaminated but regardless of the evidence this seems to be the Council's go to excuse for not have enough refuse collecting capacity.

title: Uneven road surface, potholes and loose tarmac
description:
Uneven road surface, potholes and loose tarmac: This issue relates to the large potholes that have been an issue in this area of Brownhill Road.

Leading the lights to the junction of Brownhill and Torridon there is a large stretch (about a lorry in length) of really loose and uneven road. This is just outside of 312, where a major redevelopment of the building converting what was a large house into into luxury flats is currently underway - perhaps why this patch of tarmac is now in such bad condition with large vehicles delivering and operating at the site entrance and so on.

Not only is this a safety issue for road users but also pedestrians as stones are getting constantly thrown onto the pavement and hitting the residential walls - especially with current bad, wintry weather. In addition to this, as is/was with the potholes around here they are also causing extra noise and vibrations to the properties.

Please look into resurfacing this stretch, as has been done further along asap. Thank you.

Large branches have been coming off the tree and falling onto the ground and whenever there are winds the tree sways violently.

In addition, the fence next to the tree is damaged and seems to have collapsed - leaving several rusty nails exposed and a large piece of rusted metal grating with branches sticking out of it.

Despite numerous responses today that the problem is fixed, it isn't.

Whilst most stones are not on the Calmont Road carriageway, they are on the Hillbrow Road carriageway. As the photos show, road markings indicating a bump in the road are partially covered and the direct route used by pedestrians crossing Hillbrow is covered by stones. These are particularly difficult to walk on for those in 'equality' categories eg the elderly, infirm and carers with prams. Further more, because the stones are in very close proximity to Calmont Road (and generally are all over it), this is dangerous for cyclists and in addition, car wheels can flick the stones into the air dangerously.

title: Lamps out on the footbridge
detail: The lamps along the footbridge next to the park have been out for two years and are a danger as drug addicts and dangerous criminals prey on vulnerable residents. A boycott of council taxes is an option if these lamps are not replaced so residents can feel safe when crossing during the dark
